title: National park visitors enjoy the dark
text:
National park visitors enjoy the dark Travel 
Powered by Local Corporation By Deborah Netburn LOS ANGELES TIMES • Wednesday September 9, 2015 6:09 AM 
What do you look for in a vacation? Rest and relaxation? Gorgeous vistas? How about a view of the cosmos? 
A new study suggests that gazing upon a naturally dark sky that is unpolluted by artificial light plays a significant role in visitors’ enjoyment of national parks. 
“It’s one of those things that we start to notice only when it begins to disappear,” said Bob Manning, who runs the Park Studies Laboratory at the University of Vermont. 
Scientists estimate that 99 percent of the planet’s skies are light polluted and that as of 15 years ago, two-thirds of Americans no longer could see the Milky Way from their backyards. 
The National Park Service’s Natural Sounds and Night Sky Division works to manage both acoustical and dark-night sky environments throughout the park system. 
Park managers, for example, can replace older fixtures that allow light to “leak” with those that focus light down. 
Manning’s group also conducted a survey at Acadia National Park in Maine. Park visitors were asked how important a clear view of the stars is to them. 
The results were published recently in the journal Park Science . 
Nearly all of the hundreds of groups surveyed agreed very strongly that seeing the night sky on their visit to Acadia was important to them. 
The researchers also found that when people reported seeing natural light sources such as the moon, stars, constellations and the Milky Way, it improved their experience.
